text: This reference guide is for the Tinellbian languages that descend from High Lulani. Lulani and its descendants were taken into each of the Ptokan worlds by the Guozu.

1]High Lulani WlN Created by Queen Loren on Mala Ptokonoi. I have been interested in language and linguistics since at least the age of 10. I remember making up words when I was quite young. In fact, the High Lulani word mica Mc hello dates from that time. When I decided to write a novel, a constructed language (conlang) was an obvious prospect for inclusion in the background information. I had the beginnings of what was to be the Ptokan language, and the language of the Fezhlê. The latter was once designed as a daughter language of Ptokan, but it had some features, mostly phonological, that seemed to come from an earlier language. Thus was Lulani born. Originally intended to be a phonology sketch, Lulani has expanded greatly into a language in its own right. So much so, in fact, that Ptokan and Fezhlê have been forced to change somewhat to adapt. The Tinellbian languages are a range of constructed languages, as befits the constructed universe of Tinellb. In that world, the ancestor language was created by Queen Loren of the Ptokonoi, and then evolved naturally as different groups of people moved through space, time and reality.
High Lulani is the language created by Loren, queen of the Ptokonoi. It features a semi-closed verb class and extensive compounding. It has a featural script.

High Lulani phonology has 18 consonant sounds and 3 vowels. Plosives are the only class that have a voicing distinction; fricatives are prototypically voiceless, and resonants are prototypically voiced. Vowels are defined in terms of openness and frontness; there are no oral, length or tone distinctions. All High Lulani words are formed from alternating consonant-vowel pairs. Any word-internal consonant can be geminated, which can palatalise or change the voicing of the original sound. This page will show each of the International Phonetic Alphabet characters used in High Lulani pronunciations. d columns] t]h Consonant |h Example b | ba’u bʱ | sabba c | qacca cʰ | cu’i ɕ | xu’a d | daru dʱ | ’adda f | fara g | gusu gʱ | saggi /t] t]h Consonant |h Example h | hisuba j | faʔa1 ɟ | jusi ɟʱ | majja k | takki kʰ | ka’u l | lisa ʎ | mullu m | mullu n | nisa /t] t]h Consonant |h Example ɲ | janni ŋ | qa p | ’appu pʰ | puttu r | gurrisu ɾ | rusa s | sippa t | nittu tʰ | ta’i ʔ | xu’a /t] /d] d mobile-table] t]h Consonant |h Example b | ba’u bʱ | sabba c | qacca cʰ | cu’i ɕ | xu’a d | daru dʱ | ’adda f | fara g | gusu gʱ | saggi h | hisuba j | faʔa1 ɟ | jusi ɟʱ | majja k | takki kʰ | ka’u l | lisa ʎ | mullu m | mullu n | nisa ɲ | janni ŋ | qa p | ’appu pʰ | puttu r | gurrisu ɾ | rusa s | sippa t | nittu tʰ | ta’i ʔ | xu’a /t] /d] e] 1The phone /j/ only appears as the second segment of an allophonic variant of /ʔ/, when that sound is geminated. d columns] t]h Vowel |h Example a | batu i | bitta u | cura /t] t]h Vowel |h Example ə | su’a ɨ | kasi ʉ | lulani /t] /d] The suprasegmental symbols are all exemplified in /ˌpʰam.ɨˈlam.ɨ/.
children.name: Phonology

text: Consonants are differentiated by manner and place of articulation, and by word-internal gemination. Plosives also have contrasting voice. t]|h labial |h alveolar |h retroflex |h palatal |h velar |h glottal h stop | p b | t d || c ɟ <j> | k g | ʔ <’> h nasal | m | n ||| ŋ <q> | h lateral || l |||| h tap ||| ɽ <r> ||| h fricative | f | s || ɕ <x> || h /t] d mobile-table] stops: e]labial: p e]alveolar: t e]palatal: c e]velar: k e]glottal: ʔ <’> voiced: e]labial: b e]alveolar: d e]palatal: ɟ <j> e]velar: g nasals: e]labial: m e]alveolar: n e]velar: ŋ <q> liquids: e]alveolar lateral: l e]retroflex tap: ɽ <r> fricatives: e]labial: f e]alveolar: s e]palatal: ɕ <x> e]glottal: h /d] This table shows the consonants phonemically, using the International Phonetic Alphabet. Where it differs from IPA, the transliteration is given in <triangular brackets>. Capital or geminate glottal stops are transliterated with <ʔ>. Examples: d wordlist] f]ba’u — usual word-internal glottal stop e]nasiʔu — geminate word-internal glottal stop e]’usu — usual glottal stop within sentence e]ʔusu — capitalised glottal stop at beginning of sentence e]ʔallisi — capitalised glottal stop for proper noun (Alice) /d] 1]Stops Stops are differentiated by voicing, although voiced consonants tend to be rarer than their voiceless counterparts. The voiced stops are fully voiced word-internally and partially voiced word-initially. Voiced geminate stops are given breathy voice. Voiceless stops are lightly aspirated, which is suppressed in voiceless geminate stops. Geminate stops are held for approximately twice as long as non-geminate stops. 2]Labials The plosives /p/ and /b/ are bilabial. d wordlist] f]pu’iba /pʰʉˈʔib.ə/ oib ball e]qapi /ˈŋapʰ.ɨ/ qP rope e]kuppu /ˈkʰup.pʉ/ >;o be strong e]bufi /ˈbuf.ɨ/ OF pebble e]huba /ˈhub.ə/ Vb to live e]kibba /ˈkʰibʱ.bʱə/ K;b stick /d] 2]Alveolars The plosives /t/ and /d/ are apical. d wordlist] f]turassi /tʰʉˈɽas.sɨ/ er;S redhead e]fi’atu /fɨ.ʔatʰ.ʉ/ Fae certain e]matta /ˈmat.tə/m;t again e]daru /ˈdaɽ.ʉ/ dw road e]xidu /ˈɕid.ʉ/ XE far away e]kuddu /ˈkudʱ.dʱʉ/ >;E rain /d] 2]Palatal The plosives /c/ and /ɟ/ are laminal. In fast speech, they can approach the affricates /tʃ/ and /dʒ/. d wordlist] f]cissa /ˈcʰis.sə/ C;s air e]xuci /ˈɕucʰ.ɨ/ ZC feather e]nacca /ˈnac.cə/ n;c clothing e]jagaru /ɟəˈgaɽ.ʉ/ jgw sand e]sajimu /səˈɟim.ʉ/ sJU crack e]majja /ˈmaɟʱ.ɟʱə/ m;j here /d] 2]Velars The velar plosives are /k/ and /g/. d wordlist] f]ka’u /ˈkʰaʔ.ʉ/ ku jump e]’isaki /ʔɨ.sakʰ.ɨ/ isK company e]nukki /ˈnuk.kɨ/ I;K strawberry e]gurrisu /ˈgur.rɨ.sʉ/ <;Rz door e]danagi /də.nag.ɨ/ dnG decree e]saggi /ˈsagʱ.gʱɨ/ s;G iron pyrites /d] 2]Glottal The glottal stop /ʔ/ is one of the most common sounds. Non-geminate glottal stops are often suppressed between unstressed vowels. The second of a geminate glottal stop becomes a palatal approximant /j/. d wordlist] f]’anu /ˈʔan.ʉ/ aI to balance e]kuli’a /kʰʉˈliʔ.ə/ >La friend e]nasiʔu /naˈsiʔ.jʉ/ nS;u sheep /d] 1]Nasals There are nasal consonants at each of the places of articulation of the plosives. However, the palatal nasal is only found when geminating the alveolar nasal. Nasals are prototypically voiced. Geminate nasals are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates. 2]Labial The labial nasal /m/ is bilabial. d wordlist] f]mana /ˈman.ə/ mn bubble e]salumi /səˈlum.ɨ/ sWM seven e]girammi /gɨˈɽam.mɨ/ Gr;M thunder /d] 2]Alveolar The alveolar nasal /n/ is apical. When geminated, this sound is palatal and laminal. d wordlist] f]nu /nuː/ I to stop e]lulani /lʉˈlan.ɨ/ WlN queen e]sinna /ˈsiɲ.ɲə/ S;n story /d] 2]Velar The nasal /ŋ/ is velar. d wordlist] f]quliru /ŋʉˈliɽ.ʉ/ ALw family e]kunaqi /kʰʉˈnaŋ.ɨ/ >nQ earth e]laqqu /ˈlaŋ.ŋʉ/ l;A wealth /d] 1]Liquids The liquids are mainly differentiated by laterality. This language lacks phonemic glides. Like nasals, approximants are prototypically voiced, and geminates are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates. The consonant /l/ is lateral and apical. When geminated, this sound is laminal and palatal. The consonant /ɾ/ is central, retroflex and sub-apical. When geminated, this sound becomes a trill. d wordlist] f]lassi /ˈlas.sɨ/ l;S baby e]kulu /ˈkʰul.ʉ/ >W fork e]malliju /ˈmaʎ.ʎɨ.ɟʉ/ m;LY happiness e]ru’iha /ɽʉˈʔih.ə/ wih history e]karafi /kʰəˈɽaf.ɨ/ krF enlightenment e]qarri /ˈŋar.rɨ/ q;R to open /d] 1]Fricatives Fricatives do not have complete closure of the vocal tract, but are formed with enough constriction to bring turbulence to the airstream. Fricatives are prototypically voiceless. The lips remain unrounded for all fricatives unless followed or preceded by a rounded vowel. Geminate fricatives are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates. 2]Labial The fricative /f/ is realised as labiodental. d wordlist] f]faxi /ˈfaɕ.ɨ/ fX to survive e]bufiqi /bʉˈfiŋ.ɨ/ OFQ illness e]’iffa /ˈʔif.fə/ i;f it /d] 2]Alveolar The fricative /s/ is apical. d wordlist] f]sikka /ˈsik.kə/ S;k skin e]husabi /huˈsab.ɨ/ VsB finger e]’alissa /ʔəˈlis.sə/ aL;s requirement /d] 2]Palatal The palatal fricative /ɕ/ is laminal. d wordlist] f]xaha /ˈɕah.ə/ xh name e]puxila /pʰʉˈɕil.ə/ oXl message e]dixxa /ˈdiɕ.ɕə/ D;x drink /d] 2]Glottal The fricative /h/ is a voiceless sound. When geminate, it is pronounced as a palatal fricative. d wordlist] f]hannaku /ˈhaɲ.ɲə.kʉ/ h;n> cat e]tihu /ˈtʰih.ʉ/ TV to dwell e]quhha /ˈŋuç.çə/ A;h river /d]
children.name: Consonants

text: There are three phonemic vowels, with two main allophones for each. The vowels are distinguished by closeness and frontness. t]|h front |h central |h back h close | i | (ɨ) (ʉ) | u h mid || (ə) | h open | a || /t] d mobile-table] close: e]front: i e]central: (ɨ) (ʉ) e]back: u mid: e]central: (ə) open: e]front: a /d] There are three phonemic vowels: two close vowels and one open. These are given in the above chart, with the variant allophones in (round brackets). The central and mid vowels are considered the lax variants. 1]Front The front close vowel is unrounded. It is realised as /i/ or /ɨ/. d wordlist] f]mici /ˈmic.ɨ/ MC peace e]salilu /səˈlil.ʉ/ sLW night sky e]dibada /dɨˈbad.ə/ Dbd life /d] 1]Open The open vowel is unrounded. It can be realised as /a/ or /ə/. d wordlist] f]kanama /kʰəˈnam.ə/ knm to play e]naru /ˈnaɽ.ʉ/ nw slowly e]’i’uja /ʔɨ.ʔuɟ.ə/ iuj table /d] 1]Back The back close vowel is rounded. It can be realised as /u/ or /ʉ/. d wordlist] f]mulu /ˈmul.ʉ/ UW blood e]hulla /ˈhuʎ.ʎə/ V;l to have sex e]riccu /ˈɽic.cʉ/R;y sphere /d]
children.name: Vowels

text: Phonemically, all syllables are CV, that is, one consonant followed by one vowel. Word-internal consonants can be geminated. The only consonant clusters are geminate consonants, and there are no phonemic vowel clusters or long vowels.
children.name: Phonotactics

text: 1]Syllabication Syllable breaks are placed between two geminate consonants. d wordlist] e]bat.ta /d] If there are no geminates, then the final vowel, and every second vowel going backwards are their own syllables. d wordlist] e]tuc.i e]lu.lan.i e]pam.i.lam.i /d] These two rules are in order of priority, and two closed syllables can only appear next to one another if they both end in geminates, thus: d wordlist] e]jan.ni.ga e]rad.dil.la /d] 1]Stress There are four levels of stress which are assigned to particular forms of syllables. Stress effects the quality and pitch of vowels. The top two levels are grouped together as ‘stressed’, leaving the other two levels as ‘unstressed’. 2]Primary Stress Primary stress is characterised by tense vowels with a high pitch. In polysyllabic words, primary stress falls on the last closed syllable. Monosyllabic content words also receive this stress, although this is not explicitly marked in the pronunciation guide. d wordlist] f]/tʰu/ e]/ˈbit.tə/ e]/ˈtʰucʰ.ɨ/ e]/lʉ.ˈlan.ɨ/ e]/ˌpʰam.ɨ.ˈlam.ɨ/ e]/ˈɟaɲ.ɲɨ.ɟa/ e]/ˌɽadʱ.ˈdʱiʎ.ʎə/ /d] 2]Secondary Stress Secondary stress is also characterised by the use of the tense vowels, however, the pitch is lower than the average. This falls on any other closed syllables. d wordlist] f]/ˌpʰam.ɨˈlam.ɨ/ e]/ˌɽadʱˈdʱiʎ.ʎə/ /d] 2]Tertiary Stress Tertiary stress is charateristed by use of tense vowels with a median pitch. This stress falls on any open syllable after one with quaternary stress. It is also the stress attracted by monosyllabic functional words. It is not explicitly marked; instead denoted by use of a tense vowel symbol with no stress mark. d wordlist] f]/ˈlaɲ.ɲʉ.hu/ e]/pʰi/ (functional word) e]/kʰə.lu/ (functional word) /d] 2]Quaternary Stress Quaternary stress is characterised by a lax vowel with median pitch. It is not explicitly marked. This stress falls on any open syllable directly following one with primary or secondary stress, or an initial syllable that has not yet received a stress. This latter implies that quaternary stress is assigned before the tertiary, despite being of lower rank. f]/ˈnaɽ.ə/ e]/ɕəˈnakʰ.ɨ/ 1]Vowel Length Stressed vowels are slightly longer than other vowels. WIth this proviso, long and short vowels are in free variation. An unstressed vowel between two identical consonants is elided. This elided vowel is replaced with a central dot (·) in the transliteration. This dot also appears in the compound word ku·li to distinguish it from the stem word kuli. 1]Prosody Interrogative and imperative sentences (questions and orders) are denoted by tone. This tone is either a rising tone (ǎ) or a falling tone (â), placed on the syllable of the appropriate word which has the greatest stress. Falling tone can also be used to bring focus to a particular word.
children.name: Suprasegmentals

text: As well as the syllabary for most written use, there are also special-use syllabaries. One of these encodes more redundancy for use with noisy channels. The other is a non-visual written code for blind and other visually impaired users.
children.name: Orthography

text:
The Lulani syllabary was developed as a featural script, with similar sounds having similar symbols. It is written in horizontal rows, right-to-left, and top-to-bottom. t] |h stop |h voiced |h nasal |h lateral |h tap |h fricative hr3 labial | pa: p | ba: b | ma: m ||| fa: f pi: P | bi: B | mi: M ||| fi: F pu: o | bu: O | mu: U ||| fu: v hr3 alveolar /
retroflex | ta: t | da: d | na: n | la: l | ra: r | sa: s ti: T | di: D | ni: N | li: L | ri: R | si: S tu: e | du: E | nu: I | lu: W | ru: w | su: z hr3 palatal | ca: c | ja: j |||| xa: x ci: C | ji: J |||| xi: X cu: y | ju: Y |||| xu: Z hr3 velar | ka: k | ga: g | qa: q ||| ki: K | gi: G | qi: Q ||| ku: > | gu: < | qu: A ||| hr3 glottal | ’a: a ||||| ha: h ’i: i ||||| hi: H ’u: u ||||| hu: V /t] d mobile-table] d small-table] t] ’a: a | ’i: i | ’u: u pa: p | pi: P | pu: o ba: b | bi: B | bu: O ta: t | ti: T | tu: e da: d | di: D | du: E ca: c | ci: C | cu: y ja: j | ji: J | ju: Y ka: k | ki: K | ku: > ga: g | gi: G | gu: < ma: m | mi: M | mu: U na: n | ni: N | nu: I qa: q | qi: Q | qu: A la: l | li: L | lu: W ra: r | ri: R | ru: w fa: f | fi: F | fu: v sa: s | si: S | su: z xa: x | xi: X | xu: Z ha: h | hi: H | hu: V /d] /d] Geminate consonants are shown as ;, placed before the geminated consonant. A central dot / is placed between words, and sentences begin and end with a . symbol.
children.name: Syllabary

text: There is a spelling syllabary, used for transmitting words across potentially noisy communication channels, such as telephone lines. It is also used for communicaing in situations where every syllable is important, such as giving names. Each syllable corresponds to a disyllabic word, which begins with the same consonant and ends with its vowel. The geminate symbol is represented by the word faʔa language. d left-columns] t] ’a: ’ara face pa: pacca number ba: bitta time ta: tila shell da: diha bureaucrat ca: cula egg ja: jana elder ka: kaqqa brother ga: gata pendulum ma: marru flies na: nassa euphoria qa: qasa fish la: liffa speech ra: rippa surprise fa: fipa storey sa: sinna story xa: xima morning ha: hafa race /t] t] ’i: ’ussi gift pi: paji fruit bi: basi lid ti: tuhhi farming di: dicci cold ci: cadi wall ji: jakki candle ki: kiri marigold gi: gapi soup mi: mixi room ni: niddi alertness qi: quxi mountain li: lu’i love ri: rali back fi: faxi to survive si: sutti fear xi: xalli spouse hi: huri ocean /t] t] ’u: ’iku hunger pu: pusu zirconium bu: batu group tu: tadu pig du: diru money cu: ciqu mould ju: jixu dictionary ku: kipu horse gu: gusu person mu: maʔu gingla nu: nuku world qu: qumu woman lu: laqqu wealth ru: riccu sphere fu: famu completely su: silu spouse xu: xaʔu child hu: halu algorithm /t] /d] d mobile-table] d wordlist] e]’a: ’ara face e]pa: pacca number e]ba: bitta time e]ta: tila shell e]da: diha bureaucrat e]ca: cula egg e]ja: jana elder e]ka: kaqqa brother e]ga: gata pendulum e]ma: marru flies e]na: nassa euphoria e]qa: qasa fish e]la: liffa speech e]ra: rippa surprise e]fa: fipa storey e]sa: sinna story e]xa: xima morning e]ha: hafa race e]’i: ’ussi gift e]pi: paji fruit e]bi: basi lid e] ti: tuhhi farming e]di: dicci cold e]ci: cadi wall e]ji: jakki candle e]ki: kiri marigold e]gi: gapi soup e] mi: mixi room e]ni: niddi alertness e]qi: quxi mountain e]li: lu’i love e]ri: rali back e]fi: faxi to survive e]si: sutti fear e]xi: xalli spouse e]hi: huri ocean e]’u: ’iku hunger e]pu: pusu zirconium e]bu: batu group e]tu: tadu pig e]du: diru money e]cu: ciqu mould e]ju: jixu dictionary e]ku: kipu horse e]gu: gusu person e]mu: maʔu gingla e]nu: nuku world e]qu: qumu woman e]lu: laqqu wealth e]ru: riccu sphere e]fu: famu completely e]su: silu spouse e]xu: xaʔu child e]hu: halu algorithm /d] /d]
children.name: Spelling Syllabary
Tactile Syllabary

text: High Lulani is an analytic agglutinative language, as morphemes tend to keep their own shape, even when forming words.
children.name: Morphology

text: Common and proper nouns are open classes; the pronouns are closed. 1]Common Nouns Common nouns can refer to abstract or concrete items. d wordlist] f]lu’i Wi love e]bata bt caution e]’ahati ahT happiness e]caga cg mouth e]purissiji oR;SJ circle /d] 2]Stem Nouns Stem nouns are those that are neither compounded nor derived. 3]Mass Nouns Mass nouns refer to an undifferentiated aggregation rather than separate units. These cannot take numbers, except for a postpended xita one to denote the smallest individual piece of that aggregate. d wordlist] f]’iti iT milk / ’itixita iTXt drop of milk e]marru m;w flies / marruxita m;wXt fly /d] 3]Animacy This determines which derivational suffixes can be applied, and which pronouns are used as reference. 4]Animate Noun These refer to people and other multicellular organisms capable of independent movement. d wordlist] f]gusu <z person e]lulani WlN queen e]kitisu KTz father e]sula zl goat /d] 4]Inanimate Noun These refer to things such as natural phenomena, plants, fungi and unicellular life. d wordlist] f]tissa T;s wind e]linu LI tree e]hurru V;w yeast /d] 4]Abstract Noun This category encompasses concepts, ideas and other intangibles. They are referred to by inanimate pronouns. d wordlist] f]sutti z;T fear e]’adda a;d past e]tuhhi e;H agriculture e]laru lw year e]sajja s;j silence /d] 2]Compound Nouns The first part of a compound noun must be a noun, and the subsequent parts specify the meaning of that noun. These parts can be nouns or verbs. The whole noun is usually written without spaces. The syllabification and stress of nonce words are determined on a stem-by-stem basis. However, a compound in common use will start being treated whole. d wordlist] d folding] f]jifiru’inulli e]JFwiI;L e]jifiru’i-nulli e]lake-mountain e]“mountain lake” /d] d folding] f]xu’abaju e]ZabY e]xu’a-baju e]bird-blue e]“bluebird” /d] /d] 1]Proper Nouns Proper nouns begin with a capital letter in the transliteration. These are names that refer to individual people, places or things. d wordlist] f]Ra’ani raN Ryan (name of a person) e]ʔikinnisa iK;Ns Eakins (name of a family) e]Sa’imi siM Caemi (name of a deity) e]Tinalli Tn;L Tinellb (name of a universe) e]ʔirri’a i;Ra Irìa (name of a city) e]Lulani WlN Lulani (name of a language) e]Xucipura Cula ZCor / yl The Crackled Egg (name of a story) /d]
children.name: Nouns

text: A verb is a necessary part of any sentence, except when making copular sentences. Verbs can be categorised on the basis of how many elements compose them. 2]Stem Verbs The class of stem verbs is semi-closed — there are only about 100 pure verbs in the entire language. Stem verbs consist of a single element. d wordlist] f]’i i to say e]dissu D;z to feel e]’usa us to see e]janni j;N to move e]kissa K;s to fight e]miku M> to be red /d] 2]Compound Verbs In order to extend or specify meaning, verbs can be compounded much as a noun can. Compound verbs are, however, much more common than compound nouns, to make up for the relative lack of stem verbs. d wordlist] d folding] f]’isinna e]iS;n e]’i + sinna e]say-story e]“to tell a story” /d] d folding] f]dissu’ahati e]D;zahT e]dissu + ’ahati e]feel-happiness e]“to be happy” /d] d folding] f]pamilami e]pMlM e]pa + milami e]think-surroundings e]“to be conscious” /d] /d]
children.name: Verbs

text: Intransitive verbs are monovalent. For the archetypal intransitives, the verbal patient is the subject. d folding] f]Badiri ru cura. e].bDR / w / yr. e]Badiri ru cura. e]World prs;gnopresent gnomic change. e]“The world is always changing.” /d] d wordlist] f]cura yr to change; to be different e]huba Vb to breathe; to be alive e]giri GR to conceive; to be pregnant e]gupi <P to sit down; to wait e]siku S> to die; to be dead e]hacci h;C to awaken; to be awake e]nara nr to sleep; to be asleep e]nu’ifi IiF to hide; to be hidden /d] 1]Adjectival Verbs These verbs allow the speaker to describe an attribute of the subject. d folding] f]Linu ra’u ki. / Linu qixa ki. e].LI / Qx / K . / LI / ru / K. e]Linu ra’u ki. / Linu qixa ki. e]Tree prs;stapresent stative big. / Tree prs;dynpresent dynamic big. e]“The tree is big. / The tree is growing.” /d] The actor who imparts such an attribute is put in the ablative case. d folding] f]Juffila kaluMa’iliguna pani. e].Y;Fl / kWmiL<n / pN. e]Juffila kalu-Ma’iliguna pani. e]Dragon ablablative-Maelgwn tame. e]”The dragon was tamed by Maelgwn.” /d] The experiencer who perceives such an attribute is put in the dative case. d folding] f]Liqu kuhisuba bi’u. e].LA / >Hzb / Bu. e]Liqu ku-hisuba bi’u. e]Head datdative-administrator hurt. e]lit: “The head seems sore to the administrator.” e]“The administrator has a headache.” /d] d wordlist] f]mu U good e]’anu aI balanced e]guqqi <;Q bad e]tuhi eH little e]ki K big e]ri R smooth e]qira Qr rough e]nama nm light e]kuppu >;o strong e]pani pN tame e]nittu N;e wild e]suqa zq ready e]bi’u Bu sore /d] 2]Chromatic Verbs These are adjectival verbs specifically dealing with colour. d wordlist] f]kiʔa K;a white e]ga g black e]miku M> red e]baju bY blue e]sa s yellow e]millu M;W brown /d] 1]Kinetic Verbs These verbs deal with motion of the subject. The origin of the movement is in ablative case, the destination in dative, and the general direction is marked with the adposition pa. d wordlist] f]janni j;N to accelerate; to move around e]’ussa u;s to follow e]nura Ir to leave; to be apart from e]madi mD to rise; to be high e]ka’u ku to jump e]hussu V;z to fall; to be low e]saja sj to lie down; to be lying down e]tiku T> to turn e]na n to turn towards; to face e]raca rc to be hung; to be hanging e]fiqu FA to float; to be floating e]tihu TV to move to; to abide e]malu mW to move to; to be in a place /d] 1]Quasi-Transitive Verbs These are intransitive verbs in that they do not require a noun phrase in the object position. However, they act transitively by having a second noun phrase marked in a particular way. 2]Oblique Arguments These are marked with an oblique case marker: d folding] f]Luna kalujifiru’i mala; luna kalu’ilupagu mala. e].Wn / kWJFwi / ml , Wn / kWiWp< / ml. e]Luna kalu-jifiru’i mala; luna kalu-’ilu-pagu mala. e]Moon ablablative-lake reflect; moon ablablative-heart-1genfirst person genitive reflect. e]“The moon is reflected in the lake; the moon is reflected in my heart.” /d] The usual case assignment for objects of each of these verbs is shown here: d wordlist] f]mala ml to reflect — ablative e]faxi fX to survive — dative /d] 2]Comparatives These verbs are used to denote the degree of similarity between two nouns. Their nuance can be modified by use of different case markers or adpositions. Case denotes unmarked similarity or difference, dative for the former, ablative for the latter. d folding] f]Nimalu kuquliruxita runihi. e].NmW / >ALwXt / wNH. e]Nimalu ku-quliru-xita runihi. e]Bear datdative-family-one similar. e]“The bear is like one of the family.” /d] The adposition haru hw with denotes a slight similarity or difference. d folding] f]ʔusu ra’u haruxissatanissa runihi. e].uz / ru / hwX;stN;s / wNH. e] f]ʔusu ra’u haru-xissatanissa runihi. e]1intfirst person intransitive prs;stapresent stative with-musician similar. e]“I am somewhat of a musician.” /d] The adpositions ’adi aD near and xidu XE far denote a large similarity or difference. d folding] f]Mari ra’u xidupajiga tina. e].mR / ru / XEpJg / Tn. e]Mari ra’u xidu-pajiga tina. e]This prs;stapresent stative far-olive different. e]“This is nothing like an olive.” /d] d wordlist] f]runihi wNH to be similar to e]tina Tn to be different from /d] 2]Symmetric Relations The participants of these verbs are equivalent to each other, that is, if Alice acts on Bob, then Bob acts on Alice in the same way. When the subject is Alice, say, then Bob can: 1. Be placed in the object position. Despite the structure, this is not transitive, as the verb has no passive, and pronouns use the intransitive form: d folding] f]ʔallisi sisa Bubu. e].a;LS / Ss / OO. e]ʔallisi sisa Bubu. e]Alice contact Bob. e]“Alice is touching Bob.” /d] 2. Take dative marking: d folding] f]ʔallisi kuBubu ju’i. e].a;LS / >OO / Yi. e]ʔallisi ku-Bubu ju’i. e]Alice datdative-Bob link. e]“Alice is married to Bob.” /d] 3. Be conjoined with the subject: d folding] f]ʔallisi Bubuta hulla. e].a;LS / OOt / V;l. e]ʔallisi Bubu-ta hulla. e]Alice Bob-and copulate. e]“Alice and Bob are having sex.” /d] The basic meaning of these sentences is not changed when swapping the participants or using the alternate structures. d wordlist] f]ju’i Yi to join e]sisa Ss to touch e]haru hw to accompany e]hulla V;l to copulate; to have consumated /d]
children.name: Intransitivity

text: The divalent verbs are called transitive, and these require an object to complete its meaning. It is possible to elide this object if it is obvious or irrelevant. The subject is the agent, and the object is the patient. d folding] f]Nimalu dasi (nukki). e].NmW / dS / I;K. e]Nimalu dasi (nukki). e]Bear eat (strawberry). e]“The bear is eating (the strawberry).” /d] d wordlist] e]dasi dS to consume e]nidu NE to use /d] 1]Transformative Verbs Unlike those above, these verbs involve a fundamental change to their objects. d wordlist] e]’idu iE to make e]pifa Pf to create e]pura or to change; to be e]si’a Sa to repair e]lakka l;k to break e]qarri q;R to open e]turu ew to close /d] 1]Motive Verbs The unmarked argument structure is as follows: the oblique arguments for these are the same as for kinetic verbs, i.e.: ablative source, dative destination, and direction with pa. As for the core arguments, the agent of the movement is the subject, and the patient being moved is the object. 2]Dative These are motive verbs focussing on movement to the destination. d folding] f]Suma gi pa. e].zm / G / p. e]suma gi pa. e]1trafirst person transitive carry 3ina;intinanimate third person intransitive. e]“I picked it up.” /d] The agent may be moved into the dative position, since it is identical to the destination. d folding] f]Pixi duci ’iffa. e].PX / EC / i;f. e]Pixi duci ’iffa. e]1intfirst person intransitive own 3ina;trainanimate third person transitive. e]lit: “(I) own it to me.” e]“It’s mine.” /d] An animate source may be swapped with the patient, i.e.: the ablative becoming an object and vice versa. d folding] f]ʔusu ku tali fu. e].;uz / > / tL / v. e]ʔusu ku tali fu. e]1intfirst person intransitive 3ina;datinanimate third person dative take 2trasecond person transitive. e]lit: “I took you to it.” e]“I’ve relieved you of it.” /d] d wordlist] f]duci EC to gain; to possess e]gi G to pick up; to carry e]tali tL to take /d] 2]Ablative These are motive verbs focussing on movement away from a source. d folding] f]Suma maku pa. e].zm / m> / p. e]Suma maku pa. e]1trafirst person transitive throw 3ina;intinanimate third person intransitive. e]“I threw it.” /d] Similarly to dative motive verbs, the agent can be placed in ablative position, as they are identical to the source. d folding] f]Puttu funi ’iffa. e].o;e / vN / i;f. e]Puttu funi ’iffa. e]1ablfirst person ablative lack 3ina;trainanimate third person transitive. e]lit: “(I’ve) lost it from me.” e]“I don’t have it.” /d] With similarity again to the dative verbs, an animate destination may be swapped with the patient, i.e.: with the dative becoming an object and vice versa. d folding] f]ʔusu kalu kuffa fu. e].uz / kW / >;f / v. e]ʔusu kalu kuffa fu. e]1intfirst person intransitive 3ina;ablinanimate third person ablative give 2trasecond person transitive. e]lit: “I gave you from it.” e]“I’ve given you it.” /d] d wordlist] e]kuffa >;f to give e]saki sK to share e]ga g to put e]maku m> to throw e]funi vN to lose; to lack /d] 1]Apparent Verbs These act like the transitive counterpart of the adjectival verbs, i.e.: the patient as the subject, the cause in ablative and the experiencer in dative. The additional object, which makes these transitive, is an abstract noun that refers to a quality or attribute, or an inanimate noun that refers to an actual substance or energy being released. The precise verb is chosen by whether the ‘radiation’ is physical or subtle in nature. d folding] f]Hifumari ba’u xi huba ra’u? e].HvmR / bu / X / Vb / ru. e]Hifu-mari ba’u xi huba ra’u? e]House-this 2datsecond person dative seem important prs;stapresent stative? e]“Does this house seem important to you?” /d] d folding] f]Musa xu sa’i. e].Us / Z / si. e]Musa xu sa’i. e]Sun radiate light. e]“The sun is shining.” /d] These verbs can also be used to signify the patients resemblance to something else. In this case, the other item or person is governed by the adposition ka k as. d folding] f]Filli ka’aggami xu. / Filli ka’aggami xi. e].F;L / ka;gM / X.F;L / ka;gM / Z. e]Filli ka-’aggami xu. / Filli ka-’aggami xi. e]2intsecond person intransitive as-police_officer appear. / 2intsecond person intransitive as-police_officer seem. e]“You look like a police officer.” / “You act like a police officer.” /d] d wordlist] f]xi X to broadcast subtly e]xu Z to broadcast physically /d] 1]Vital Verbs These verbs require that both their objects and subjects are animate. d wordlist] e]kuli >L to meet; to know e]ca c to help e]hisu Hz to administer e]kissa K;s to fight e]’ussa u;s to obey /d] 1]Action Verbs These verbs take an activity as an object. These can take the form of pure nouns: d folding] f]Hisutuba tara sinna. e].Hzeb / tr / S;n. e]hisutuba tara sinna. e]Babysitter begin story. e]“The babysitter started the story.” /d] They can also take gerunds: d folding] f]Kipu nu dasiruqa hafi. e].Ko / I / dSwq / hF. e]Kipu nu dasi-ru-qa hafi. e]Ox stop eat-gergerund-gengenitive grass. e]“The cow stopped its eating of the grass.” /d] d wordlist] f]la l to do e]tara tr to begin e]tuni eN to repeat e]nu I to stop e]naqa nq to need e]tapu to look forward to; to enjoy /d]
children.name: Transitivity

text: Ambitransitive verbs can be used with or without an argument in the object position. 1]Perceptive Verbs These verbs deal with the subject’s ability to perceive stimuli. When used purely intransitively, i.e.: with no direct or dative object, they refer to a general ability to use that sense: d folding] f]Guli ruku ’usa. e].<L / w> / us. e]Guli ruku ’usa. e]Blind_person fut;gnofuture gnomic see. e]“The blind person can now see.” /d] When used with a direct object, this denotes a conscious effort at perception: d folding] f]Ju’ipu’a ’usa bumaki. e].Yioa / us / OmK. e]Ju’ipu’a ’usa bumaki. e]Assembly see screen. e]“The audience watched the screen.” /d] When used with a dative object, this instead lacks that effort: d folding] f]Mihu kulasidaxi ju’isataduru ’usa. e].MV / >lSdX / YistEw / us. e]Mihu ku-lasida-xi ju’isatadu-ru ’usa. e]3ani;intanimate third person intransitive datdative-secret-seem conversation-gergerund see. e]“She saw the secret meeting.” /d] d wordlist] f]’usa us to see e]hulu VW to hear e]cussi y;S to feel e]ji’i Ji to taste e]cikki C;K to perceive e]dissu D;z to emote e]lu’i Wi to love e]qacca q;c to choose e]qi Q to experience /d] 1]Communicative Verbs The communication itself is the object, and the recipient is dative. d folding] f]Kimilli kul·lani ’i ’issi. e].KM;L / >WlN / i / i;S. e]Kimilli ku-lulani ’i ’issi. e]King datdative-song speak queen e]“The king sang to the queen.” /d] Indirect speech is signified by a complement object. d folding] f]Kimilli jusi ’i li lu’i lulani ru. e].KM;L / >L / Wi / WlN / w / i / MV. e]Kimilli jusi ’i li lu’i lulani ru. e]King 3ani;datanimate third person dative speak comcomplementiser love queen prs;gnopresent gnomic. e]“The king told him he loved the queen.” /d] Directly reported communication is separated from the main clause by a comma, and may be put on either side. In this case, the recipient may be in either the object position or dative. This argument structure can also be used without a specific communication. d folding] f](Mica,) kimilli ’i lulani. e].Mc , KM;L / i / WlN. e](Mica,) kimilli ’i lulani. e](Hello,) king speak queen. e]“The king said ‘hello’ / spoke to the queen.” /d] d wordlist] f]’i i to speak e]buma Om to draw e]pa p to think e]ma m to consider /d]

text:
Auxiliaries are a type of verb, however, they are sufficiently different from main verbs for them to be treated separately in this grammar. They are used to mark tense (the time at which an action takes place) and aspect (the nature of the passage of time during the action). The auxiliary can be dropped from a sentence if it is obvious from context, or is the same as that of the sentence immediately prior. They are a closed class. t]|h dynamic |h stative |h negative |h habitual |h gnomic h past | qixa

w> /t] d mobile-table] past: e]dynamic: qixa Qx e]stative: pi P e]negative: qilu QW e]habitual: taku t> e]gnomic: rusa ws present: e]dynamic: cani cN e]stative: ra’u ru e]negative: ji J e]habitual: na n e]gnomic: ru w future: e]dynamic: lanu lI e]stative: nagi nG e]negative: funi vN e]habitual: hu V e]gnomic: ruku w> /d] Auxiliary stacking gives a poetic or archaic nuance. d folding] f]ʔusu rusarukuru lu’i fu. e].uz / wsw>w / Wi / v. e]ʔusu rusarukuru lu’i fu. e]1intfirst person intransitive pst;gnopast gnomic-fut;gnofuture gnomic-prs;gnopresent gnomic love 2trasecond person transitive. e]“I have always and will always love you.” /d] 1]Tense The three tenses are past, present and future. In conversation, the tenses tend to mark the time at which the action began or occurred. On the other hand, narratives are mainly told in present tense. The other tenses are then used relatively, so that past tense is used for things that happened earlier than the narrative present, and the future tense for things that happened later. d folding] f]Quhu qixa dasi si’apa pada, jimuli cani janni qu, lanu haruqikanni la kiluqu. e].AV / Qx / dS / Sap / pd , JUL / cN / j;N / A , lI / hwQk;N / l / KWA. e]Quhu qixa dasi si’apa pada, jimuli cani janni qu, lanu haru-qikanni la kiluqu. e]3ani;traanimate third person transitive pst;dynpast dynamic eat meal and_then, outside prs;dynpresent dynamic move and, fut;dynfuture dynamic with-dog do walk. e]lit.: She did eat the meal, and then is going outside, and will do a walk with a dog. e]“She ate the meal, went outside and walked the dog.” /d] 1]Aspect The aspects of positive polarity can be categorised in two different ways. Each of these has two possibilities, and thus there are four altogether: t]|h episodic |h generic h activity | dynamic | habitual h state | stative | gnomic /t] d mobile-table] activity: e]episodic: dynamic e]generic: habitual state: e]episodic: stative e]generic: gnomic /d] There is a single category of auxiliaries with the opposite polarity — the negative. 2]Episodic and Generic The difference between episodic and generic markers is one of extent. Events in episodic sentences take place over a finite duration; generic ones are prototypically unbounded, although this doesn’t literally have to cover all of time. d folding] f]Pannaxa cani ’ibibu. / Pannaxa na ’ibibu. e].p;nx / n / iBO .p;nx / cN / iBO . e]Pannaxa cani ’ibibu. / Pannaxa na ’ibibu. e]Warrior prs;dynpresent dynamic complain. / Warrior prs;habpresent habitual complain. e]Episodic: “The warrior is complaining now.” / Generic: “The warrior always complains.” /d] 2]Activity versus State The difference between activity and state for most verbs is one of focus, ie.: emphasis can be placed on the event itself (activity), or on the results (state). d folding] f]ʔa’ima cani duci sunu. / ʔa’ima pi duci sunu. e].aim / P / EC / zI. aim / Qx / EC / zI. e]ʔa’ima qixa duci sunu. / ʔa’ima pi duci sunu. e]Traveller pst;dynpast dynamic possess cloak. / Traveller pst;stapast stative possess cloak. e]Activity: “The traveller gained a cloak.” / State: “The traveller owned a cloak.” /d] Perceptive verbs are treated slightly differently. Here, dynamic and habitual markers act as normal, however, the stative and gnomic are used to denote an ability to perceive a stimulus. d folding] f]Fu ’usa gufu’iribuma cani? / Filli ’usa gufu’iribuma ra’u? e]. F;L / us / <viROm / ru . v / us / <viROm / cN. e]Fu ’usa gufu’iribuma cani? / Filli ’usa gufu’iribuma ra’u? e]2trasecond person transitive see television prs;dynpresent dynamic? / 2intsecond person intransitive see television prs;stapresent stative? e]Activity: “Are you watching the TV?” / State: “Can you see the TV?” /d] 2]Negative The negative aspect is used for actions, attributes and perceptions which do not occur. These act as the negation of any other aspectual marker. That is, while positive sentences can be classified by aspect, negative sentences all use the same auxiliaries.
children.name: Auxiliaries

text: Adpositions are a closed class. They can be used in three different ways. 2]As a Preposition The most basic use for an adposition is prefixed to a noun to signify where the action is taking place with relation to a reference. These act as prefixes. d wordlist] d folding] f]di’i’uja e]Diuj e]di-’i’uja e]up-table e]“atop the table” /d] d folding] f]harul·lani e]hwWlN e]haru-lulani e]with-queen e]“with the queen” /d] d folding] f]nicula e]Nyl e]ni-cula e]at-egg e]“in an egg” /d] /d] Their nature as a prefix continues to apply even when the noun is already case-marked d folding] f]qakalu’ita’i e]qkWiti e]qa-kalu-’ita’i e]down-ablablative-car e]“down from the cart” /d] 2]As a Nominal or Verbal Modifier Adpositions can be used to form compound nouns: d folding] f]gusu’adi e] <zaD e]gusu-’adi e]person-near e]“nearby people” /d] and compound verbs: d folding] e]jannigibi e] j;NGB e]janni-gibi e]move-east e]“to go east” /d] 2]As an Adverb Adpositions can be used independently to show the position of the action relative to the speaker, or the direction in which the action proceeds. Unlike other adverbs, these are placed before or instead of the auxiliary. d folding] f]Luxira’uxxi qu’u cani dasi. e].WXru;X / Au / cN / dS. e]Luxira’uxxi qu’u cani dasi. e]Twins inside prs;dynpresent dynamic eat. e]“The twins are eating inside.” /d] d folding] f]Kuddu qa hussu. e]. >;E / q / V;z. e]Kuddu qa hussu. e]Rain down fall. e]lit: “Rain is falling down.” e]“It’s raining.” /d] The auxiliary must appear to support an adverbial adposition in copular clauses. d folding] f]Nimalu sani ra’u. e].NmW / sN / ru. e]Nimalu sani ra’u. e]Bear north prs;stapresent stative. e]“The bear is to the north.” /d] d folding] f]Kuhisuba ’adi na cijja. e].>Hzb / aD / n / C;j. e]Ku-hisuba ’adi na cijja. e]datdative-administrator near prs;habpresent habitual alcohol. e]“The minister is usually having a drink around now.” /d] 1]Directions This list includes both relative and absolute terms. d wordlist] f]saqa sq right e]gi G left f]ka k south e]sumika zMk west e]sani sN north e]gibi GB east /d] 1]Locations These can be used to refer to locations in either space or time. d wordlist] f]’adi aD near / now e]xidu XE far / then f]di D up / upstream e]qa q down / downstream f]’ari aR front / before e]capi cP behind / after f]pa p towards / at e]ni N at / during e]kika Kk over / over /d] 1]Spatial Locations These can only be used to refer to locations in space. d wordlist] f]jimuli JUL outside e]qu’uAu in; inside e]nifi NF beside e]raqu rA among e]ca c encircling e]du’iEi beyond e]la’a la on a horizontal surface e]kadu kE on a vertical surface /d] 1]Motion These refer to motion. d wordlist] f]data dt backwards e]tirri T;R forwards e]ja j along e]ma’iki miK across e]tiku T> around e]bi B out of /d] 1]Animates This group have animate objects. d wordlist] f]haru hw with e]ha h for the benefit of /d] 1]Inanimates This group have inanimate objects. d wordlist] f]nidu NE using e]sarru s;w instead of e]haru hw consisting of e]nina Nn used for a purpose e]sata st in order to obtain e]’arri a;R along with /d]

text: Adverbs are a closed class. Adverbs can be used either as a verbal suffix or independently to describe the entire utterance. See Also: Adverbial Clauses d wordlist] f]matta m;t also e]gicirri GC;R instead e]naku n> together e]basa bs unlawfully /d] 2]Purpose d wordlist] e]piddi P;D on purpose e]qiriji QRJ with effort e]hibu HO allow oneself to e]dumi EM try to e]danna d;n successfully e]ca’alla ca;l must e]fuca vc can e]ritada Rtd by fate e]macu my unexpectedly e]xani xN unwillingly e]dukku E;> not by choice /d] 2]Extent d wordlist] f]dapi dP more than is necessary e]famu fU completely e]rali rL intensely e]kupira >Pr in many different ways e]ti’ici TiC to a certain extent e]cipati CpT to that extent e]tuci eC barely e]miru Mw about to e]xibbuti X;OT never again /d] 2]Time d wordlist] f]xuga Zg instantly e]cidatu Cde suddenly e]karu kw commonly e]gaqqu g;A usually e]naru nw slowly e]nigi NG quickly e]dura Er repeatedly /d] 1]Modals These adverbs cannot be used as verbal suffixes, and can only describe an entire sentence. d wordlist] f]matta m;t again e]hiru Hw contrariwise /d] 3]Likelihood These tell how likely an event is to have occurred, or to occur in the future. d wordlist] f]’ili iL actually e]da’aru daw experience e]fa f maybe e]tasi tS probably e]qaxa qx predicted to e]mica Mc permitted to e]nufira IFr want to e]rixi RX would be better to /d] 3]Evidential These give the means by which the speaker gained information with regards to their utterance. d wordlist] f]raqa rq obviously e]da d clearly e]jami jM evidentially e]qaffi q;F seemingly e]jati jT apparently e]xakila xKl thought to be e]lisina LSn by assumption e]rafa rf by hearsay /d] 3]Emotion These convey the feelings of the speaker towards the utterance or the listener. d wordlist] f]pu’i oi incredulity (“I can’t believe it!”) e]rapi rP disregard (“I don’t care!”) e]tappa t;p seeking confirmation (“Isn’t it?”) e]rani rN giving confirmation (“I agree.”) e]qarihu qRV regret (“I’m sorry.”) e]tupi eP respect (“With all due respect…”) /d] 1]Derivation Suffixes can derive adverbs from other parts of speech. Zero-derivation, i.e.: having a null suffix, is also productive for some categories of words, such as references to time, which are used as modals. d wordlist] f]musa Us today e]laru lw this year e]tariti tRT at noon /d] Numbers can be suffixed to denote other times. d wordlist] d folding] f]musahha e]Us;h e]musa-hha e]day-zero e]lit: “0-day” e]“yesterday” /d] d folding] f]musara e]Usr e]musa-ra e]day-two e]lit: “2-day” e]“tomorrow” /d] d folding] f]larumullu e]lwU;W e]laru-mullu e]year-minus_one e]lit.: “1-day” e]“two years ago” /d] /d]
children.name: Adverbs

text:
Suffixes can be used to derive new word from existing vocabulary. A suffix beginning with a vowel replaces the final vowel of the base. 1]Derivational Suffixes These derive words within a class, i.e.: a noun from a noun, or a verb from a verb. The augmentative -aku /a> is most often attached to nouns to reference something large or important. It is rarely used for people. d wordlist] f]tissaku T;s> wind e]’isilaku iSl> depression /d] The diminutive -ini /iN is used to form words which reference something small or unimportant. When used with animate nouns, it creates a word for the young of non-sapient creatures. However, with sapient creatures, this word is obscene. d wordlist] f]’ahatini ahTN contentment e]tissini T;SN breeze e]qikannini Qk;NN puppy e]ranini rNN potato chips f]bi’ini BiN to itch /d] The honorific -fi F confers a nuance of sacredness upon a base word. d wordlist] f]karafi krF sacredness e]lulanifi WlNF great queen /d] The pair -tu’i ei and -da d are used to highlight the positive and negative aspects of a word, respectively. d wordlist] f]dasatu’i dsei passion / dasada dsd anger e]ta’itu’i tiei aroma / ta’ida tid stink /d] 2]Nominal suffixes These derive nouns from other nouns. t]| inanimate base | abstract base h animate | -rra

j | /t] d mobile-table] inanimate e] → animate: -rra ;r e] → abstract: -ja j abstract e] → animate: -sa s / -ri R e] → inanimate: -di D /d] The above table shows the suffixes used for deriving nouns between different animacy classes. An animate noun is derived from an inanimate noun by the suffix -rra ;r. d wordlist] f]tisakarra Tsk;r townsperson /d] Both -sa s and -ri R derive an animate noun from an abstract noun, however, these are not predictable. For instance, note the difference between dis·sa D;zs youth and dissuri D;zR stranger. Other examples are: d wordlist] f]pucasa ocs optimist e]sasa ss introvert e]dattusa d;es god e]mulisa ULs fool e]luxirasa WXrs twin e]tuhhisa e;Hs farmer f]’axasiri axSR adult e]’asilari aSlR friend /d] The -ri R suffix also denotes people from a particular place. d wordlist] f]Tinalliri Tn;LR Tinellbian /d] The suffix -di D derives an inanimate noun from something abstract, and -ja j does the opposite. d wordlist] f]sinnadi S;nD book f]ru’ihaja wihj history /d] The suffix -li L derives nouns which are somehow distinct from their stem. d wordlist] f]daruli dwL wrong way e]gusuli non-Guozu person /d] The names of parts of the body are derived using -kku ;> on either nouns or verbs. d wordlist] f]’itikku iT;> breast e]mulukku UW;> heart f]dasikku dS;> digestive system /d] The animate giver of the inanimate or abstract base is denoted by -mi M. d wordlist] f]’aggami a;gM police officer / law giver e]Sa’imi siM Caemi / light giver /d] The feminine and masculine are denoted by -qi and -kati respectively, however, they are infrequently used. 2]Verbal suffixes These are only applied to verbs. The suffix -ni N is used to derive inceptive verbs. d wordlist] f]ducini ECN to receive /d] The suffix -ulu /uW denotes reversal of an action, and can only be applied to stem verbs. d wordlist] f]lulu WW to undo e]jannulu j;IW to return e]turulu ewW to open e]ju’ulu YuW to unlink /d] The repetition marker -tuni eN has similar form and meaning to the full verb tuni eN repeat. d wordlist] f]latuni leN to do again /d] The augmentative -ssasu ;sz is used specifically for verbs. d wordlist] f]bi’ussasu Bu;sz to really hurt /d] 2]Auxiliary Infix The infix -ar- is placed before the final vowel of auxiliaries, and denotes an end to the action described by the sentence. d wordlist] f]lanaru lnw will finish doing e]nagari ngR will finish being /d] 2]Adverbial Suffixes There are two kinds of negation for adverbs. The suffix -hita Ht is standard negation. d wordlist] f]jamihita jMHt not in evidence e]’ilihita iLHt not in reality /d] On the other hand, -ma m forms terminatives, i.e.: the situation described by the adverb was true in the past, but no longer applies. d wordlist] f]nufirama no longer wanting e]dumima no longer trying /d] 1]Nominalisation These derive a noun from another part of speech, most often a verb. The suffix -qa q derives generic nouns from numerals or alienable genitive pronouns. d wordlist] f]disiqa DSq hers f]nuruqa Iwq the four of them /d] The suffix -muka Uk is used with prepositional phrases. d wordlist] f]disinnamuka DS;nUk prologue /d] Other suffixes in this group are divided into animacy classes. 2]Abstract The productive general suffix -’a a derives abstract nouns. d wordlist] f]cura’a yra time e]qacca’a q;ca choice e]pa’a pa thought /d] The suffix -ru w forms gerunds. d wordlist] f]dasiru dSw eating e]janniru j;Nw moving e]hubaru Vbw breathing /d] The suffix -ci is applied to adjectival verbs. This includes chromatic verbs, whence come the name for colours. d wordlist] f]namaci nmC weakness e]kiʔaci K;aC white /d] Application of -ppa ;p derives terms for times and occasions. d wordlist] f]dasippa dS;p mealtime e]sikuppa S>;p funeral /d] The suffix -ahi is used with adverbs. d wordlist] f]nufirahi IFrH expectation /d] 2]Inanimate The patientive suffix -du E is applied to stem verbs. d wordlist] f]dasidu dSE food e]maladu mlE reflection e]kassudu k;zE trade goods /d] The instrumental suffix -ffi ;F is applied to a verb. d wordlist] f]dasiffi dS;F cutlery, tools for eating e]sikuffi S>;F spear, tool for killing /d] The suffix -kku ;> derives names for parts of the body from verbs or nouns. d wordlist] f]dasikku dS;> digestive system e]’itikku iT;> breast e]mulukku UW;> heart /d] When applied to a number, -ssiji ;SJ gives rise to the names of shapes. d wordlist] f]kifissiji KF;SJ triangle e]nurussiji Iw;SJ quadrilateral /d] 2]Animate There are three suffixes for deriving animate nouns from verbs. The suffix -la’i is used with intransitive verbs, while -ba and -pu’a derive generic agents and patients respectively. d wordlist] f]narala’i nrli sleeper f]’ussaba u;sb follower e]caba cb helper e]hisuba Hzb administrator f]ju’ipu’a Yioa group e]lu’ipu’a Wioa lover e]cikkipu’a C;Koa telepath /d] 1]Adverbialisation The pair of suffixes -atinna /aT;n and -niqqi N;Q derive adverbs from verbs and nouns respectively. d wordlist] f]’usatinna usT;n visibly e]katinna kT;n increasingly e]lu’atinna WaT;n lovingly f]’ahatiniqqi ahTN;Q happily e]’isilakuniqqi iSl>N;Q depressingly e]bataniqqi btN;Q carefully e]bufiniqqi OFN;Q stonily e]ga’iniqqi giN;Q in time /d]
children.name: Suffixes

text: A determiner can be used to narrow the reference of a noun. They appear at the end of a noun phrase, after any normal suffixes. They do not move the stress of the noun, and can only receive up to secondary stress themselves. d wordlist] f]cama cm usual e]nisa Ns only e]sabufi sOF different /d] 2]Quantity These are used to answer ”how many?” d wordlist] f]mimu’i MUi some e]lumi WM several e]raqi rQ more e]’uhu uV many e]takki t;K many /d] 2]Choice There are two sets of determiners that are both used to select a part from the whole. One group is used with count nouns, the other with mass nouns. 3]Count Nouns These refer to particular members of a group. d wordlist] f]ca c only e]fi’atu Fae certain e]tapa tp next e]cari cR remaining e]qafa qf last /d] 3]Mass Nouns These refer to sections of a substance. d wordlist] f]cari cR remaining e]sukki z;K entire /d] 2]Degree These mark the degree to which the noun matches its referent. d wordlist] f]nata nt complete e]naci nC somewhat e]ji’a Ja not /d]
children.name: Determiners

text: Deixis encompasses words and phrases which rely on an external context to complete their meaning. 1]Topicality Once a topic is introduced in a discourse or narrative, it can be assumed to be the subject until changed. 1]Pro-forms The two groups of pro-forms are classified on the basis of their semantic properties. Definite pro-forms are those that encode case, person, animacy and topicality. Indefinite pro-forms comprise the remaining deictic terms.
children.name: Deixis
