text: Conjunctions are a closed class of words which are used to join phrases or clauses together. 1]Phrase-level Conjunctions These conjunctions are used to join words or phrases. They are enclitics on the second and subsequent nouns. d wordlist] f]-ta t and e]-sija Sj or /d] 1]Clause-level Conjunctions These conjunctions are used to join clauses or sentences. They are used as independent words. 2]Coordinating Conjunctions Coordinating conjunctions are used to separate two matrix clauses. They are placed at the beginning of the second clause. d wordlist] f]qu A and e]nuki IK or e]pada pd and then /d] 2]Subordinating Conjunctions Subordinating conjunctions are used to introduce a dependent clause. See the section on subordinate clauses for syntactical information. d wordlist] f]surra if e]daru’i because e]gi’a Ga that is e]gi’ika Gik in order to e]ma when e]rika and thus e]haru hw while e]fati fT enough to /d]
children.name: Conjunctions

text: There are very few particles. These are simply words that do not fit neatly into any other category. This includes: l]interjections, numbers, pronouns of the alienable genitive, content and relative clause introductory markers, and the superlative marker. /l]

These are exclamations that do not fit the syntactic rules of the other parts of speech, hence their classification among the particles. All interjections end with the same vowel, either naturally, d wordlist] f]ta t um e]ti’a Ta oh! /d] or because the interjection marker -a /a has derived them from nouns or verbs. d wordlist] f]mica Mc hello e]nara nr goodbye; good night e]hacca h;c good morning e]kica Kc what? e]hira Hr please; thank-you /d]
children.name: Interjections
Particles

text: High Lulani is head-initial in compounds, but tends to be head-final in phrases and clauses. The language has Subject-Verb-Object order, but shows signs of an SOV nature, as dative and ablative complements become more common.

1]Alignment The three basic arguments for any verb (intransitive subjects, transitive subjects and transitive objects) are marked in High Lulani. Because intransitive subjects cannot co-occur with transitive arguments, it is possible to mark either of the transitive arguments in the same way as the intransitive without confusion. In the ergative alignment, it is the transitive object that is marked the same as the intransitive subject. In accusative alignment, it is instead the transitive subject that shares marking with intransitive subjects. In either alignment, the intransitive case is the one treated like the intransitive subject, and the transitive case is the other. High Lulani has an ergativity split, made down aspectual lines. A clause using dynamic or iterative auxiliaries uses ergative alignment; gnomic, stative and negative aspects attract the accusative. 1]Core Cases The core cases mark the basic arguments of the verb. Common or proper nouns have no case markings for these, but the pronouns have different forms. Therefore only pronouns show the alignment of a sentence. 2]Intransitive The intransitive case is used for the sole argument of an intransitive verb and for the unmarked argument of transitive sentences. This case is also used for adpositions. 2]Transitive The transitive case is used for the marked argument of transitive sentences, that is, the object in an accusative clause, and the subject in ergative clauses. 1]Oblique Cases The two oblique cases are marked on the pronouns. For common and proper nouns, a clitic with the same form as the appropriate third person inanimate pronoun is placed before the noun phrase. Sometimes the verb requires an oblique rather than a traditional object. In these cases, the subject is usually in intransitive case, although it is not incorrect to use transitive case with dynamic and iterative auxiliaries. 2]Ablative The ablative case is used to mark the proximate cause or the instigator of an action. With verbs of transfer or motion, it is also used to mark the source of a movement. d wordlist] f]sacu sy because of you / from you /d] The clitic is kalu- kW. d folding] f]kaluTinalli janni e] kWTn;L / j;N e]kalu-Tinalli janni e]ablablative-Tinellb move e]“come from Tinellb” /d] d folding] f]kalukimilli kuffa e]kWKM;L / >;f e]kalu-kimilli kuffa e]ablablative-king give e]“given by the king” /d] 2]Dative The dative case was originally only used to mark the receiver with verbs of giving and transfer. The meaning has since broadened to show indirectness on the part of the patient for a number of verbs, including verbs of perception and emotion. d wordlist] f]pixi PX to me /d] The clitic is ku- > . d folding] f]kuʔirri’a janni e]>i;Ra / j;N e]ku-’irri’a janni e]datdative-Irìa move e]“go to Irìa” /d] d folding] f]kululani kuffa e]>WlN / >;f e]ku-lulani kuffa e]datdative-queen give e]“give to the queen” /d]
children.name: Case

text: The standard word order for matrix clauses is: Subject ‐ Auxiliary ‐ Adposition - Oblique ‐ Verb ‐ Object ‐ Adverb. None of these slots are compulsorily filled. If a subject is obvious from context, or is the same as that of the immediately prior sentence, it can be dropped. The adverb can act as a pro-sentence. 1]Intransitive Clauses As already discussed, intransitive clauses do not have objects. d folding] f]Mihu ra’u nara. e].MV / ru / nr. e]Mihu ra’u nara. e]3int prs;stapresent stative sleep e]“He is asleep.” /d] 1]Transitive Clauses Transitive clauses do require an object. d folding] f]ʔusu ru lu’i fu. e].uz / w / Wi / v. e]ʔusu ru lu’i fu. e]1intfirst person intransitive prs;gnopresent gnomic love 2trasecond person transitive. e]“I love you.” /d] Sometimes the object is in an oblique case. d folding] f]Mihu ra’u kuqikanni ’usa. e].MV / ru / >Qk;N / us. e]Mihu ra’u kuqikanni ’usa. e]3ani;intanimate third person intransitive prs;stapresent stative datdative-dog see. e]“She can see the dog.” /d] 1]Copular Sentences Copular sentences do not have a main verb. These sentences are used to show an equivalence relationship between two nouns, or to show that one noun is an element of the set described by the other noun. They are transitive sentences. d folding] e]Mihu lanu julliga. e].MV / lI / Y;Lg. e]Mihu lanu julliga. e]3ani;intanimate third person intransitive fut;dynfuture dynamic married_woman e]“She will become a married woman.” /d] Another use of copular sentences is to tell the location of something in relation to something else. d folding] f]Pa ra’u di’i’uja. e].p / ru / Diuj. e]Pa ra’u di’i’uja. e]3ina;intinanimate third person intransitive prs;gnopresent gnomic down-table e]“It’s under the table.” /d] The copular sentence structure for ownership is as follows. It has the possessor in the dative case, and the possessum as the subject. d folding] f]Sunu ru pixi. e].zI / w / PX. e]Sunu ru pixi. e]Cloak prs;gno 1dat e]I have a cloak. /d] The arguments may be swapped without a change in meaning. d folding] e]Pixi ru sunu. e].PX / w / zI. e]Pixi ru sunu. e]1dat prs;gno cloak. e]I have a cloak. /d] 1]Contrasting Pronouns These example sentences have been given to clarify alignment and the correct use of pronouns with different auxiliaries. d folding] f]Mihu qixa miku. e].MV / Qx / M>. e]Mihu qixa miku. e]3ani.int pst;dyn red e]“She turned red.” /d] d folding] f]Mihu pi miku. e].MV / P / M>. e]Mihu pi miku. e]3ani.int pst;sta red e]“She was red.” /d] d folding] f]Quhu qixa dasi pa. e].AV / Qx / dS / p. e]Quhu qixa dasi pa. e]3ani.tra pst;dyn eat 3ina.int e]“She ate it.” /d] d folding] f]Mihu pi dasi ’iffa. e].MV / P / dS / i;f. e]Mihu pi dasi ’iffa. e]3ani.int pst;sta eat 3ina.tra e]“She was eating it.” /d] As can be seen, the only time the transitive case is used for the subject of a clause is in transitive (as well as copular) sentences using dynamic or iterative auxiliaries.
children.name: Matrix Clauses

text: The first noun in a clause is the subject, which is prototypically the agent in transitive sentences and the patient in intransitive sentences. However, suffixes can be added to the verb to promote other nouns in the clause, other than the genitive. There are three such verbal suffixes, which can be stacked, however, once something has been shifted from the subject position, it can’t be promoted again. 1]Passive The passive suffix promotes the object. This suffix has the forms: l] -’illu i;W when the last element of a verb is monosyllabic, -ilu /iW replacing the final vowel if the final consonant is geminated, and -illu /i;W replacing the final vowel of the verb elsewise. /l] The old subject is then marked with the ablative case. A sentence with this marker is intransitive. The demoted item is not compulsory, but if it is put in, it is the first ablative-marked noun in the new sentence. d folding] f]Fu qixa kissa kilatu’i! e].v / Qx / K;s / Klei. e]Fu qixa kissa kilatu’i! e]2tra pst;dyn fight deer e]“You fought a deer!” /d] d folding] f]Kilatu’i qixa (sacu) kissilu. e].Klei / Qx / sy / K;SW. e]Kilatu’i qixa (sacu) kissa-ilu. e]deer pst;dyn (2abl) fight-psv e]“A deer was fought (by you).” /d] 1]Ablative The ablative suffix promotes the ablative. It has the form: l] -ka k when the final consonant of a verb is geminate, or -kka ;k elsewise. /l] The old subject is demoted to object, and the old object is demoted to dative. A sentence with this marker is transitive. The first dative-marked noun in the new sentence is the demoted item. d folding] f]Lulani qixa kalukimilli dasi qasa. e].WlN / Qx / kWKM;L / dS / qs. e]Lulani qixa kalu-kimilli dasi qasa. e]queen pst;dyn abl-king eat fish e]“The queen ate a fish because of the king.” /d] d folding] f]Kimilli qixa kuqasa dasikka lulani. e].KM;L / Qx / >qs / dS;k / WlN. e]Kimilli qixa ku-qasa dasi-kka lulani. e]king pst;dyn dat-fish eat-abp queen. e]“The king made the queen eat fish.” /d] d folding] f]Kimilli qixa (kal·lani) dasilluka qasa. e].KM;L / Qx / kWWlN / dS;Wk / qs. e]Kimilli qixa kalu-lulani dasi-illu-ka qasa. e]king pst;dynpast dynamic (abl-queen) eat-psv-abp fish e]“The king made the fish get eaten (by the queen).” /d] 1]Dative The suffix -xa promotes a dative. The old subject is demoted to object, and the old object (if any) is demoted to dative. A sentence with this marker is transitive. d folding] f]Mulisa ru kuquxi kuffa laqqu. e].ULs / w / >AX / >;f / l;A. e]Mulisa ru ku-quxi kuffa laqqu. e]fool prs;gno dat-mountain give money. e]“A fool gives money to the mountain.” /d] d folding] e]Quxi ru kulaqqu kuffaxa mulisa. e].AX / w / >l;A / >;fx / ULs. e]Quxi ru kulaqqu kuffaxa mulisa. e]mountain prs;gnopresent gnomic datdative-money give-dtvdative promotion fool e]“It is to the mountain that fools give money.” /d] d folding] f]Quxi ru (kalumulisa) kuffiluxa laqqu. e].AX / w / kWULs / >;FWx / l;A. e]Quxi ru (kalumulisa) kuffa-ilu-xa laqqu. e]mountain prs;gnopresent gnomic (ablablative-fool) give-psvpassive-dtvdative promotion money. e]“It is to the mountain that money is given (by fools).” /d] 1]Adposition To promote a adpositional phrase to subject, prefix the verb with the adposition. The old subject is demoted to object. The old object, if any, is demoted to dative. d folding] f]Mihu pi nijagaru gupi. e].MV / P / Njgw / <P. e]Mihu pi ni-jagaru gupi. e]3ani;intanimate third person intransitive pst;stapast stative at-sand sit e]“She sat in the sand.” /d] d folding] f]Jagaru pi nigupi quhu. e].jgw / P / N<o / AV. e]Jagaru pi ni-gupi quhu. e]sand pst;stapast stative at-sit 3ani;traanimate third person transitive e]“It was the sand that she sat in.” /d] d folding] f]Mihu pi nijagaru dasi nukki. e].MV / P / Njgw / dS / I;K. e]Mihu pi ni-jagaru dasi nukki. e]3ani;intanimate third person intransitive pst;stapast stative at-sand eat strawberry e]“He was eating a strawberry in the sand.” /d] d folding] f]Jagaru pi kunukki nidasi quhu. e].jgw / P / >I;K / NdS / AV. e]Jagaru pi ku-nukki ni-dasi quhu. e]sand pst;stapast stative datdative-strawberry in-eat 3ani;traanimate third person transitive. e]“It was in the sand that he was eating the strawberry.” /d]
children.name: Argument Promotion

text: A dependent clause is a clause that is unable to stand meaningfully by itself. They are marked by having the auxiliary at the end. 1]Subordinate Clauses A subordinate clause is one introduced by a subordinating conjunction in the matrix clause. A comma is used to separate a subordinate from its matrix. The conjunction is placed on the side of the main clause that is closest to the subordinate. The clauses can be put in either order. d folding] f]ʔusu ru lu’i fu daru’i, ba pu’iba miku ra’u. e].uz / w / Wi / v / dwi , b / oib / M> / ru. e]ʔusu ru lu’i fu daru’i, ba pu’iba miku ra’u. e]1intfirst person intransitive prs;gnopresent gnomic love 2trasecond person transitive because, 2gensecond person genitive ball red prs;stapresent stative e]“I love you because your ball is red.” /d] d folding] f]Ba pu’iba miku ra’u, daru’i ’usu ru lu’i fu. e].b / oib / M> / ru , dwi / uz / w / Wi / v. e]Ba pu’iba miku ra’u, daru’i ’usu ru lu’i fu. e]2gensecond person genitive ball red prs;stapresent stative, because 1intfirst person intransitive prs;gnopresent gnomic love 2trasecond person transitive e]“I love you because your ball is red.” /d] Here the subordinate clauses are hightlighted. The cause is subordinate to the effect. 2]Location Adverbial Clauses The word ma m where is often used as a prefix for adpositions used as clausal conjunctions. d folding] f]ʔusu lu’i fu madi, ba pu’iba miku qixa. e].uz / Wi / v / mD , b / oib / M> / Qx. e]ʔusu lu’i fu ma-di, ba pu’iba miku qixa. e]1intfirst person intransitive love 2trasecond person transitive where-up, 2gensecond person genitive ball red pst;dynpast dynamic. e]“I loved you before your ball turned red.” /d] 1]Content Clauses A content clause is one that takes the place of a noun. They begin with the complementiser li L and are separated from the matrix clause by commas. The auxiliary is not optional, and is given a low tone. Quote marks are used around reported speech, replacing the complementiser. d folding] f]Li ’usu kissajisuka kugibiʔasi’a rusa, qixa puttu pa’illu. e].L / uz / K;sJzk / >GB;aSa / ws , Qx / o;e / pi;W. e]Li ’usu kissa-jisuka ku-gibiʔasi’a rusa, qixa puttu pa-’illu. e]1intfirst person intransitive fight-ideology datdative-east-Asia pst;gnopast gnomic, pst;dynpast dynamic 1ablfirst person ablative think-psvpassive e]“That we’ve always been at war with Eastasia, is what I think.” /d] d folding] f]Suma qixa kul·lani ’icipu, li quhu pixi kuffa dissudanagi qixa. e].zm / Qx / >M;lN / iCo , L / AV / PX / >;f / D;zdnG / Qx. e]Suma qixa ku-lulani ’icipu, li quhu pixi kuffa dissu-danagi qixa. e]1trafirst person transitive pst;dynpast dynamic datdative-queen ask, comcomplementiser 3ani;traanimate third person transitive 1datfirst person dative give new-decree pst;dynpast dynamic e]“I asked the queen if she had pardoned me.” /d] d folding] f]Mihu qixa ’i, “Filli mulisa ra’u?” e].MV / Qx / i , AF;L / ULs / ruA. e]Mihu qixa ’i, “Filli mulisa ra’u?” e]3ani;intanimate third person intransitive pst;dynpast dynamic speak “2intsecond person intransitive fool prs;stapresent stative?” e]“He said, ‘Are you a fool?’” /d] 1]Relative Clauses Relative clauses specify the noun by describing it. They begin with the relativiser xiku X> and are placed before the modified noun, The auxiliary is not optional, and is given a rising tone. Only subjects can be relativised. Other cases must be promoted to subject. d folding] f]Xiku lu’i kimilli pi lulani. e].X> / Wi / KM;L / P / WlN. e]Xiku lu’i kimilli pi lulani. e]relrelativiser love king pst;stapast stative queen e]“The queen who loved the king.” /d] d folding] f]Xiku kalukimilli lu’illu pi lulani. e].X> / kWKM;L / Wi;W / P / WlN. e]Xiku kalu-kimilli lu’i-illu pi lulani. e]relrelativiser ablablative-king love-psvpassive pst;stapast stative queen. e]“The queen whom the king loved.” /d] Any noun can be modified by relative clauses, including pronouns and proper nouns. d folding] f]Xiku lu’i kimilli pi mihu. e].X> / Wi / KM;L / P / MV. e]Xiku lu’i kimilli pi mihu. e]relrelativiser love king pst;stapast stative 3ani;intanimate third person intransitive e]“The one who loved the king.” /d] d folding] f]Xiku lu’i kimilli pi Sa’imi. e].X> / Wi / KM;L / P / siM. e]Xiku lu’i kimilli pi Sa’imi. e]relrelativiser love king pst;stapast stative Caemi e]“Caemi, who loved the king.” /d] 2]Intransitives If the only argument of the relative verb is the modified noun, the auxiliary is appended to the verb, and the relativiser is dropped. This auxiliary is given a mid-tone. d wordlist] d folding] f]dissu’ahatira’u mulisa. e].D;zahTru / ULs. e]feel_happy-prs;stapresent stative fool e]dissu’ahatira’u mulisa e]“the happy fool” /d] d folding] f]’ibibuna suma e]iBOn / zm e]complain-prs;habpresent habitual 1trafirst person transitive e]’ibibuna suma e]“the occasionally complaining me” /d] d folding] f]ka’ucani Ra’ani e]kucN / raN e]jump-prs;dynpresent dynamic Ryan e]ka’ucani Ra’ani e]the jumping Ryan /d] /d] Similar are intransitives utilising the case markers and other adpositions. d wordlist] d folding] f]kalukimilli nuhu. e].kWKM;L / IV. e]kalu-kimilli nuhu e]ablablative-king folding_paper e]“the letter from the king” /d] d folding] f]kul·lani nukki. e].>WlN / I;K. e]ku-lulani nukki e]ablablative-queen strawberry e]”the strawberry for the queen“ /d] d folding] f]di’i’uja pa e]Diuj / p e]di’i’uja pa e]up-table 3ina;intinanimate third person intransitive e]“the thing atop the table” /d] /d] 2]Transitives If the only arguments of the relative verb are the modified noun and a direct object, the verb is appended to the object, with or without the auxiliary, and the relativiser is dropped. d folding] f]xucipura cula e]ZCor / yl e]xuci-pura cula e]feather-change egg e]“hatching egg” /d] d folding] f]hafidasira’u kipu e]hFdSru / Ko e]hafi-dasi-ra’u kipu e]grass-eat-prs;stapresent stative ox e]“the grass-eating cow.” /d] 1]Questions and Requests Questions and requests are main clauses, but have the same auxiliary movement as dependent clauses, and thus are treated alongside them here. 2]Interrogatives An interrogative is a question sentence. There are two main types, polar questions and content questions. Polar questions are one in which the answer is “yes” or “no”. They are spoken with a rising tone on the last word. The auxiliaries are used to answer. d folding] f]Lulani lu’i suma ra’u? e].WlN / Wi / zm / ru. e]Lulani lu’i suma ra’u? e]queen love 1trafirst person transitive prs;stapresent stative? e]“Does the queen love me?” /d] d folding] f]Ra’u. / Ji. / Ruku. / Pi. e].P.w>.J.ru. e]Ra’u. / Ji. / Ruku. / Pi. e]prs;stapresent stative. / prs;negpresent negative. / fut;gnofuture gnomic. / pst;stapast stative. e]“Yes.” / “No.” / “She will.” / “She did.” /d] d folding] f]Lulani nimalu ji? e].WlN / NmW / J. e]Lulani nimalu ji? e]queen bear prs;negpresent negative? e]“Is the queen not a bear?” /d] d folding] f]Ji. / Ra’u. / Na. e]n.ru.J e]Ji. / Ra’u. / Na. e]prs;negpresent negative. / prs;stapresent stative. / prs;habpresent habitual. e]“Yes, she’s not.” / “No, she is.” / “Usually.” /d] If the focus of the question is on a particular noun, that noun receives a falling tone. Content questions are ones in which the expected answer is more than just “yes” or “no”. These questions have a rising tone on the main question word itself. d folding] f]Lulani lu’i sama ra’u? e].WlN / Wi / sm / ru. e]Lulani lu’i sama ra’u? e]Queen love what prs;stapresent stative? e]“Whom does the queen love?” /d] d folding] f]Kimilli. / Fu. / Cu’i. e].yi.v.KM;L. e]Kimilli. / Fu. / Cu’i. e]King. / 2trasecond person transitive. / Nothing. e]“The king.” / “You.” / “No one.” /d] 2]Imperatives An imperative statement is an order. Second person imperatives are directed to the listener. In these, the subject is dropped, a future auxiliary in the appropriate aspect is suffixed to the verb, and this verb complex is moved to the end of the sentence. These are spoken with a falling tone on the auxiliary. d folding] f]Lulani lu’iruku! e].WlN / Wiw>. e]Lulani lu’i-ruku! e]Queen love-fut;gnofuture gnomic! e]“Love the queen!” /d]
children.name: Dependent Clauses

text: The full noun phrase is made up of these components in the following order: n]adposition- case marker- number relative clause main noun -determiner -conjunction -genitive marker /n] The highlighted component denotes the only one that is compulsory, i.e.: the main noun itself. The hyphens represent the lack of a word space in both the Tinellbian script and the transcription. d wordlist] f]faluki fWK (v) journey d folding] f]kukimilli (ii-v) e]>KM;L e]ku-kimilli e]ablablative-king e]“to the king” /d] d folding] f]diku’i’uja (i-ii-v) e]D>iuj e]di-ku-’i’uja e]up-datdative-table e]“onto the table” /d] d folding] f]harubijju nimalu (i-iii v) e] hwB;Y / NmW e]haru-bijju nimalu e]with-first bear e]“with the first bear” /d] d folding] f]xiku dasi nukki na gusulumi (iv v-vi) e]X> / dS / I;K / n / <zWM e]xiku dasi nukki na gusu-lumi e]relrelativiser eat strawberry prs;habpresent habitual person-several e]“several people who eat strawberries” /d] d folding] f]kaluxiku kuluna ’usi na ’aba (ii-iv v) e]kWX> / >Wn / uS / n / ab e]kalu-xiku ku-luna ’usi na ’aba e]ablablative-relrelativiser datdative-moon see prs;habpresent habitual all e]“because of everyone who looks at the moon” /d] d folding] f]’adira qikannihisupi xaʔu (i-iii iv v) e]aDr /Qk;NHzP / x;u e]’adi-ra qikanni-hisu-pi xaʔu e]near-two dog-administer-pst;stapast stative child e]“near the two children who had looked after dogs” /d] d folding] e]julliga nuraqixa kasataqa ’ara (iv v-vii-viii) e]Y;Lg / IrQx / kstq / ar e]julliga nura-qixa kasa-ta-qa ’ara e]mother leave-pst;dynpast dynamic man-and-gengenitive face e]the faces of the mothers and the men who left. /d] /d]
children.name: Noun Phrases

text: The gerund suffix -ru w changes basic verbs into nouns describing the activity. d wordlist] f]hubaru Vbw breathing e]malaru mlw reflecting e]mikuru M>w being red /d] Compound verbs, as well as those involving noun incorporation, can also be changed like this. d wordlist] f]dissu’ahatiru D;zahTw feeling happy e]pakicuru pKyw believing to be true e]’i’issiru ii;Sw singing /d] The genitive determiners, including -qa q, allow for (only) the subject of the verb to be mentioned. d wordlist] d folding] f]jannikiluquruqa nimalu e]j;NKWAwq / NmW e] f]jannikiluqu-ru-qa nimalu e]walk-gergerund-gengenitive bear e]“the bear’s walking” /d] d folding] f]guqqirupahi e]<;QwpH e]guqqi-ru-pahi e]bad-gergerund-1genfirst person genitive e]“my being bad” /d] /d] This continues to apply in instances using argument promotion. d wordlist] d folding] f]dasilluruqa dasu e]dS;Wwq / dz e]dasi-illu-ru-qa dasu e]eat-psvpassive-gergerund-gengenitive meat e]“the eating of meat” /d] d folding] e]sikukkarudisi e]S>;kwDS e]siku-kka-ru-disi e]die-abvablative promotion-gergerund-3ani;genanimate third person genitive e]“his murdering of another” /d] d folding] f]’usaxaruqa luna e]usxwq / Wn e]’usa-xa-ru-qa luna e]look-dtvdative promotion-gergerund-gengenitive moon e]“looking at the moon” /d] /d]
children.name: Gerunds
Syntax

text: This section details particular categories of vocabulary items.
children.name: Apocrypha

text: 1]Cardinal Numbers The number system in High Lulani uses balanced sesquidecimal (base 15), and so numbers are written with the positive digits (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7), their negative counterparts (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7) and a zero (0). A period (fractional point: . ) is used to separate the integer part of the number from the mantissa. A comma (,) is used in the integer part to separate the digits into groupings of four, beginning from the fractional point. 2]One-digit Numbers Here are the names for the one-digit numbers: d left-columns] t] (qi)hha | Q;h | 0 xita | Xt | 1 ra | r | 2 kifi | KF | 3 nuru | Iw | 4 guhi | <H | 5 ’usi | uS | 6 salumi | sWM | 7 /t] t] (qi)hha | Q;h | 0 mullu | U;W | 1 kannu | k;I | 2 bila | Bl | 3 missu | M;z | 4 laffi | l;F | 5 jusiti | YST | 6 haki | hK | 7 /t] /d] d mobile-table] d wordlist] e](qi)hha Q;h 0 e]xita Xt 1 e]ra r 2 e]kifi KF 3 e]nuru Iw 4 e]guhi <H 5 e]’usi uS 6 e]salumi sWM 7 e]haki hK 7 e]jusiti YST 6 e]laffi l;F 5 e]missu M;z 4 e]bila Bl 3 e]kannu k;I 2 e]mullu U;W 1 /d] /d] The full form qihha Q;h zero is only used when by itself, or first in a number or noun phrase. 2]Two-digit Numbers Numbers between 17 and 16 are composed of the prefix sa- s and the final two syllables of the number, except for salura (not sara) 12. Round numbers, i.e.: numbers ending with a single zero, use the suffix -hha ;h. d wordlist] f]sahha s;h‎ 10 e]rahha r;h 20 e]kifihha KF;h 30 /d] All other two digit numbers, except for 22, are formed by juxtaposing the tens digit with the units. d wordlist] f]mullukifi U;WKF 13 e]xitasalumi XtsWM 17 e]ranuru rIw 24 e]kifilaffi KFl;F 35 /d] The word for 22, the exception, is ranira rNr. 2]Three- and Four-digit Numbers Three- and four-digit numbers are divided into the number of hundreds, and the remainder. This remainder is always the last two digits of the number. The word for 100 is takki t;K. Other three-digit numbers beginning with a 1 are formed by prefixing this word to the remainder, while even larger three- and four-digit numbers append it to the number of hundreds, which is then followed by the remainder as a separate word. d wordlist] f]takkinurukannu t;KIwk;I 142 f]guhitakki ’usibila <Ht;K / uSBl 563 e]sahhatakki kifinuru s;ht;K / KFIw 1034 e]kannuratakki missumullu k;Irt;K / M;zU;W 2241 /d] In any of these cases, if the remainder is zero, it is left off. d wordlist] f]mullutakki U;Wt;K 100 e]ratakki rt;K 200 e]saguhitakki s<Ht;K 1500 e]bilasalumitakki BlsWMt;K 3700 /d] 2]Higher and Lower Order Numbers When a number is written out in digits, each set of four digits from the fractional point makes up a group. The group furthest from the fractional point may not have this full quota of digits. An index marker notes the identity of a particular group. The index marker is composed of the prefix pa- p followed by the number of groups between this one and the fractional point. Positive index numbers are for the integer part of the number, and negative index numbers are for the mantissa. The index marker is suffixed to the group word. d wordlist] f]paxita pXt 1,0000 e]para pr 1,0000,0000 e]pakifi pKF 1,0000,0000,0000 e]pamullu pU;W 0.0001 e]samissu paxita sM;zpXt 14,0000 e]takkiranira paxita t;KrNrpXt 122,0000 e]’usitakki mullura paxita uSt;K / U;WrpXt 612,0000 /d] There is nothing preventing an index-marked number being used within another index marker, although the second pa- is usually geminated. d wordlist] f]pappaxita p;pXt 1,00001,0000 e]papappaxita pp;pXt 1,00001,0000^1,0000 /d] 2]Non-integral Numbers 3]Reading Mantissas There are two ways to read a mantissa. One uses the above method of index markers, and the second reads out the digits in pairs or individually. These methods are often combined: using index markers for the first digit groups, and then continuing to read digits separately. 3]Repeating and Reflecting Strings All rational numbers end with a repeating string of digits. For some numbers, this string is “0”. In non-zero cases, the word tuni eN repeat is inserted before the repeating string. The string must be read out with individual digits. There are also numbers for which the repeating string can be cut in half, with digits in the second half being the negative of the digits in the first half. For these, only the first half is read out, with the word mala ml reflect inserted. f]tuni guhira eN / <Hr 0.5252… e]paqihha xita tuni guhira pQ;h / Xt / eN / <Hr 0.15252… e]paqihha xita mala guhira pQ;h / Xt / ml / <Hr 0.152525252… 3]Fractions The suffix -ki K separates the numerator from the denominator. Saki sK is used if the numerator is 1. There is also a commonly used variant for ½: ’ima im. d wordlist] f]’ima / saki ra sK / r . im ½; e]saki kifi sK / KF ⅓ e]kifiki nuru KFK / Iw ¾ /d] 1]Ordinal Numbers Ordinal numbers are used to mark position in a line or a list. The first two ordinal numbers are suppletive, that is, they are not related to their cardinals. All other ordinals are formed by adding the suffix -uju Y to the cardinal number. d wordlist] f]bijju B;Y 1st e]matta m;t 2nd e]kifuju KvY 3rd e]nuruju IwY 4th e]salumuju sWUY 7th e]saqikkuju sQ;>Y 10th e]saxituju sXeY 11th e]takkuju t;>Y 100th /d] 1]Using Numbers Ordinal and cardinal numbers are used in noun phrases, and are inserted between any case markers or adpositions, and the noun. d wordlist] d folding] f]nuruju kimilli e]IwY / KM;L e]nuru-uju kimilli e]four-ord king e]“the fourth king” /d] d folding] e]kalusalumi lulani e]kWsWM / WlN e]kalu-salumi lulani e]ablablative-seven queen e]“due to the seven queens.” /d] /d] Numbers can be suffixed to a noun to denote not the quantity, but a quality. d wordlist] d folding] f]salumi sinnadi e]sWM / S;nD e]salumi sinnadi e]seven book e]“seven books” /d] d folding] f]sinnasalumi e]S;nsWM e]sinnasalumi e]story-seven e]“septet” /d] /d] The number ra r two can be used in this way to refer to a pair of something. d wordlist] f]luffura W;vr eyes e]’itikkura iT;>r breasts e]tibara Tbr legs /d]

text: The basic colour terms are all verbs: d wordlist] f]baju bY blue e]sa s yellow e]miku M> red f]millu M;W brown f]kiʔa K;a white e]ga g black /d] Baju bY blue covers both light and dark blue, the darkest violets, and all but the lightest shades of green. Sa s yellow covers the lightest shades of orange and green, as well as standard yellow. Miku M> red refers to all of red and pink, light purples and most of the orange spectrum, however, dark orange is subsumed under millu M;W brown. The figure above shows which shades are referred to by which term. Kiʔa K;a white is used to refer to very light greys, as well as the usual white. Ga g black is used to refer to the darker greys, tending towards the black. All colour terms can be compounded to refer to specific hues. d wordlist] f]mikumulu M>UW blood red e]bajukunubi bY>IB sky blue e]kiʔamasi K;amS snow white /d]
children.name: Colours

text:
1]Marriage Ju’idukuru YiE>w marriage is the life-bonding of two people. It is intended to be eternal, but can be broken if requested by either partner. It is not an exclusive arrangement, and one can be involved in concurrent marriages. A bonded person is called a silu SW spouse when using possessive pronouns, and xalli x;L married person otherwise. 1]Nuclear Family The words kitisu KTz father and julliga Y;Lg mother usually refer to biological parents, but can be applied to the main guardians if the biological parents are not around. These are used without possessives, except for -qa q gengenitive the inalienable genitive marker. The following table shows the possessive forms: t]|h mother |h father h 1st person | pi’apagu
Pap< | sappagu
s;p< h 2nd person | pihaba
Phb | sabba
s;b h 3rd person topic | pihasu’a
Phza | sassu’a
s;za h 3rd person animate | pi’adisi
PaDS | saddisi
s;DS /t] d mobile-table] mother: e]first person: pi’apagu Pap< e]second person: pihaba Phb e]third person topic: pihasu’a Phza e]third person animate: pi’adisi PaDS father: e]first person: sappagu s;p< e]second person: sabba s;b e]third person topic: sassu’a s;za e]third person animate: saddisi s;DS /d] There are two terms for children: tu e offspring for postnatal children, ’appu a;o foetus for antenatal. Both of these are gender-neutral, and are most often used with possessives. There can be a suffixed ju’i Yi link for spouses’ offspring and parents’ spouses. d wordlist] d folding] f]sappaguju’i e]s;p<Yi e]sappagu-ju’i e]father;1gengenitive-link e]“my step-father” /d] d folding] f]tuju’iba e]eYib e]tu-ju’i-ba e]offspring-link-2gengenitive e]“your step-daughter” /d] /d] Other kinship terms began as nuclear family names, but were thence extended across a generation. So kaqqa k;q elder sibling and kica Kc younger sibling can also be applied to cousins.

text: While High Lulani continued being used in the Palace and its surrounds, the living language continued to evolve in the mouths of the people.

Where it differs from IPA, the transliteration is given in < triangular brackets >. 1]Vowels t]|h front |h central |h back h close | i y < ü > || u h mid | e (ø < ö >) | (ə) | (o) h open | æ || /t] d mobile-table] close: e]front unrounded: i e]front rounded: y < ü > e]back rounded: u mid: e]front unrounded: e e]front rounded: (ø < ö >) e]central: (ə) e]back rounded: (o) open: e]front: æ /d] 2]Allophony Unstressed vowels are realised as ə. Rounded vowels are lowered, i.e.: u → o and y → ø, before peripheral consonants. The latter change also occurs at the ends of words.

1]Irregular Verbs
These are derived from monosyllables.
children.name: Verbs

text: This page includes a list of changes from High Lulani to Demotic Lulani. 1]Phonology A detailed up-to-date list of changes in kept at GitHub, in a Python file that applies these changes to a High Lulani word. l]Lowering of back vowels before peripheral consonants. Shifting of geminate consonants: unvoiced plosive → voiced plosive → voiced fricative I-mutation of vowels when followed by /i/ in the next syllable. Palatalisation of alveolar sounds when followed by /i/. Loss of /i/ after geminate consonants. Degemination of consonants. Elision of unstressed /ə/, followed by consonant cluster reduction. Reduction of remaining unstressed vowels to schwa. This can be transliterated with a lower dot on the affected vowel. /l] 1]Morphology 2]Verbs and adjectives Auxiliaries were cliticised onto verbs. From a combination of stress patterns and elision / reduction of unstressed vowels, verbs became trigrade. Adjectives developed from verbs originally followed by monosyllabic auxiliaries, i.e.: grade one and grade zero verbs. Grade two verbs remained verbs, however, the meaning of the auxiliaries has shifted. f]Grade zero: e]< verb > + -hu → emotional adjectives f]Grade one: e]< verb > + -pi → positive adjectives e]< verb > + -ji → negative adjectives e]< verb > + -ru → abstract gerund e]< verb > + -na → concrete gerund f]Grade two: e]< verb > + -qixa → past perfect e]< verb > + -cani → non-past perfect e]< verb > + -taku → past imperfect e]< verb > + -ra’u → non-past imperfect e]< verb > + -qilu → negative e]< verb > + -lanu → positive imperative e]< verb > + -funi → negative imperative e]< verb > + -rusa → past historic e]< verb > + -ruku → future historic e]< verb > + -nagi → Ø 1]Syntax The dative began to take over the functions of the accusative, which was thereby dropped.
